Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Examining the links between Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation and Atlantic Multidecadal Variability
Award.AbstractNarration:
It is well recognized that the meridional overturning circulation in the Atlantic Ocean (referred to as the AMOC) is an important factor controlling ocean heat transport in the North Atlantic, changes in this transport can affect ocean surface temperatures, atmospheric circulation and hence climate. Another notable feature of the North Atlantic seen in observations and models is the pronounced, spatially coherent, variability in the North Atlantic sea surface temperatures on decadal to multi-decadal timescales referred to as Atlantic Multidecadal Variability (AMV). With a typical periodicity of about 50 years, the AMV sea surface temperature variability impacts key climate characteristics, ranging from precipitation to tropical cyclone activity. The extent to which AMOC variability and the AMV are independent, and to which the latter reflects the former, remains hotly debated. One difficulty in resolving this debate is the short duration of available observations; another is that across the models, AMOC variability, including its periodicity, amplitude, and effect on SST, varies broadly. Accordingly, the main objective of this project is to establish the robust mechanisms of AMOC variability and its connection with the AMV, and at the same time to systematically explore the causes of these inter-model differences. This is of strong practical value as the AMOC is shown to be the most predictable component of the climate system on decadal timescales - progress in decadal prediction requires a better understanding of AMOC variability and its impacts. Funding from this grant will support the career growth of a female early career scientist, a graduate and undergraduate student and two postdoctoral associates. The project will enhance the climate modeling capacity by graduate and undergraduate students at both George Mason and Yale, and will facilitate the exchange of expertise between the two universities. This project will support several educational broader impacts including participation in GMU's Aspiring Scientists Summer Internship Program, benefiting high-school students and undergrads, public lectures and Teacher Development workshops at the Peabody Museum of Natural History.


This is a modeling proposal to study decadal to multi-decadal variability of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and its effect on climate in the North Atlantic, specifically on AMV, also referred to as the Atlantic Multidecadal Oscillation (AMO). The core approach lies in exciting or isolating AMOC internal modes and assessing their contribution to the AMV. The project will include several interrelated components: (i) Multi-decadal numerical experiments using several global climate models selected to represent inter-model differences in AMOC characteristics, in which we will excite AMOC variations by prescribing specifically chosen initial conditions - oceanic optimal initial perturbations in temperature or salinity. (ii) An analysis of the CMIP5 dataset focusing on AMOC internal modes and their effect on the AMV. (iii) A complementary analysis of an ocean eddy-resolving climate simulation. (iv) Observational analysis identifying periods of possible AMOC mode activity that we will then simulate with decadal reforecast experiments initialized by different ocean reanalysis products, thereby testing the impact of ocean state on the decadal evolution of the North Atlantic SST anomalies and the AMV. Throughout these analyses the properties of AMOC internal modes and the links between the AMOC and AMV will be assessed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this collaborative project is to study decadal, multi-decadal and longer variability of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) and its effects on climate in the North Atlantic, specifically on North Atlantic sea surface temperature (SST) and Atlantic Multidecadal Variability (AMV). Our core approach lies in isolating AMOC modes of variability and/or forcing AMOC variations externally in climate models and assessing the contribution of those variations to SST variability. In parallel, we investigate the fundamental physical mechanisms of AMOC stability, variability and change in a warming climate. Some of the key findings of this work are summarized below:

AMV-AMOC links. We investigated the connection between AMOC variability and AMV across the models of the Climate Model Intecomparison Project Phase 6 (CMIP6). The ocean’s role in AMV remains intensely debated since the AMV spatial patten can be reproduced in models without active ocean dynamics. We have shown that intrinsic AMOC variability produces an array of AMV-like responses across climate models. Whilst pre-industrial simulations nearly all exhibit an AMV-AMOC relationship with the AMOC leading AMV, we find no inter-model consensus on the strength and phasing of the connection as the AMV-AMOC temporal correlation coefficients range from 0.3 to 0.8. The strength of the inferred AMV-AMOC relationship appears to be set by the intensity of midlatitude westerlies that control which sites of oceanic deep convection dominate the meridional overturning (Studholme and Fedorov 2021).

The impacts of the AMOC slowdown in a warming climate. We developed a novel method to study the climatic effects of a weakening AMOC on the future climate (Liu et al. 2020). This method stabilizes the AMOC intensity in anthropogenic climate warming numerical experiments by gradually removing freshwater from the subpolar North Atlantic at a rate sufficient to keep the AMOC strength unchanged. Our results show that the weakened AMOC can explain ocean cooling south of Greenland that resembles the North Atlantic Warming Hole (a region in the North Atlantic with SST trends showing suppressed warming over the past century) and a reduced Arctic sea ice loss in all seasons with a delay of about 6 years in the emergence of an ice-free Arctic in boreal summer. In the troposphere, the weakened AMOC causes a poleward displacement of the Northern Hemisphere midlatitude jets.

The effect of enhanced Indian ocean warming on the AMOC. We investigated how a salient feature of global warming, the enhanced warming of the tropical Indian Ocean (TIO), affects the AMOC and hence the North Atlantic climate (Hu and Fedorov 2019, 2020, Ferster et al. 2021). A surprising result is that TIO warming has a stabilizing effect on the AMOC, which may be partially counteracting the AMOC slow-down due to the increased stratification in the North Atlantic caused by global warming. This effect is explained by atmospheric teleconnections connecting TIO to the North Atlantic.

AMOC stability and sensitivity to external perturbations. We also examined the problem of AMOC stability and its effect on climate. In particular, we investigated the response of the AMOC to external forcing (freshwater, CO2, Arctic sea ice decline) in the context of AMOC stability. We find that the more stable the AMOC is, the smaller sensitivity to external forcing it demonstrates, leading for example to dramatically different AMOC responses to Arctic sea ice decline in climate models. For example, in a model with a less stable AMOC, sea ice decline comparable to the observed over the past decades results in a 30-40% slowdown of the AMOC, but in a model with a more stable AMOC, the AMOC slows down only by about 10% but then fully recovers (Li et al. 2021).

AMOC slowdown and recovery under a steady external forcing. We investigated the mechanisms of a partial AMOC recovery after its initial decline caused by climatic forcing and studied its SST manifestation. We demonstrates that slow subsurface density changes introduce a negative feedback that partially reinvigorates convection and the AMOC and ensure the meridional heat transport weakens less than the AMOC (Thomas and Fedorov 2019).

Funding from this grant supported collaboration between PI Fedorov at Yale and a female early career researcher, PI Burls, at George Mason University (GMU). As part of this project, Fedorov supervised two postdoctoral associates and an undergraduate student. Fedorov co-authored 11 publications, including several papers in such journals as Nature Climate Change, Nature communications and Science Advances and a comprehensive review article focusing on the stability of the AMOC (Weijer et al. 2019). The results of the project have been also presented at invited and regular talks by the PIs at the AGU, EGU, Ocean Sciences and other conferences and workshops. Lastly, this project enhanced the capacity for global climate modeling and analysis by graduate and undergraduate students at both George Mason and Yale.
